title: The Immune Threshold Hypothesis: Why Cancer Rates Are Rising Faster in Young Adults
topic_summary: Explores a threshold-based immune depletion model to explain why cancer rates are rising faster in younger adults than seniors, contradicting standard epidemiological models. Presents data, mechanisms, predictions, and policy implications.
target_audience: General public with interest in health trends, medical professionals, researchers in oncology and immunology.

scenes.title: The Paradox
scenes.narration_summary: Introduce the counterintuitive rise in cancer rates among young adults, citing key statistics and establishing the core question.

scenes.title: The Standard Model Fails
scenes.narration_summary: Explain why catch-up effects and screening expansions don't explain the sustained acceleration.

scenes.title: Immune Surveillance as Renewable Resource
scenes.narration_summary: Describe immune surveillance with depletion threshold, contrasting gradual vs rapid depletion.

scenes.title: The Cumulative Burden Formula
scenes.narration_summary: Introduce the mathematical model linking burden to cancer rates, visualizing regime shift.

scenes.title: The Age Inversion Prediction
scenes.narration_summary: Present the hypothesis's testable prediction of faster rises in young adults, with cancer type distinctions.

scenes.title: The Biological Mechanism
scenes.narration_summary: Detail cellular-level changes from repeated stimulation, IgG4 elevation, and immune evasion.

scenes.title: The Policy Implication
scenes.narration_summary: Discuss burden reduction via booster de-escalation and early screening as the intervention point.

scenes.title: Conclusion - The Test
scenes.narration_summary: Summarize predictions and emphasize the next 36 months as decisive data window.
